citations.narrative:
The perimeter fence, at an access gate facing the parking lot at the front of the facility, is inadequate as follows:
• To the left and right of this gate, the fence is not the required 8 feet (96 inches) in height for dangerous animals. Instead,
the fence measures approximately 92 to 94 inches for a few feet in both directions away from the gate.
• There is a significant gap below the right side of the gate ranging from 5 to 7 inches in height which doesn't adequately
prevent other animals from passing through it.
The lack of an adequate perimeter fence presents a safety risk to the animals within the facility in that there isn’t an
adequate secondary containment system to hold animals that may escape their primary enclosures or a sufficient barrier
to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. The facility must ensure they maintain in good repair a continuous 8-foot-
high perimeter fencing for dangerous animals (bears). Such fences must be at least 3 feet in distance from the primary
enclosure for animals housed outdoors.
Correct by: December 25, 2024.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
n

narrative:
3.127(d) 
   
Facilities, outdoor. 
The perimeter fence, at an access gate facing the parking lot at the front of the facility, is inadequate as follows: 
• To the left and right of this gate, the fence is not the required 8 feet (96 inches) in height for dangerous animals. Instead, 
the fence measures approximately 92 to 94 inches for a few feet in both directions away from the gate.  
• There is a significant gap below the right side of the gate ranging from 5 to 7 inches in height which doesn't adequately 
prevent other animals from passing through it. 
The lack of an adequate perimeter fence presents a safety risk to the animals within the facility in that there isn’t an 
adequate secondary containment system to hold animals that may escape their primary enclosures or a sufficient barrier 
to keep animals and unauthorized persons out. The facility must ensure they maintain in good repair a continuous 8-foot-
high perimeter fencing for dangerous animals (bears). Such fences must be at least 3 feet in distance from the primary 
enclosure for animals housed outdoors. 
Correct by: December 25, 2024. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with a facility representative.
